conclusion: Two particles, A and B, move along the same horizontal plane, starting from rest, at the same position, and in the same direction. The question asks for the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases.
The graph is a velocity-time (v-t) graph with time (t) on the x-axis and velocity (v) on the y-axis. Markings are at times t0, 2t0, 3t0, up to 6t0.
Particle A's velocity increases to 2v0 at t0 and then decreases to zero by 3t0. Particle B's velocity increases to v0 at 5t0 and decreases to zero by 6t0.

premise: Both particles start from rest, so their initial velocities are zero.
conclusion: The initial velocities of particles A and B are zero.

premise: The graph shows particle A accelerates to 2v0 in time t0 and decelerates to zero in the next 2t0 (from t0 to 3t0).
conclusion: Particle A accelerates to 2v0 in t0 and decelerates to zero from t0 to 3t0.

premise: The graph shows particle B accelerates to v0 in 5t0 and decelerates to zero in the last t0 (from 5t0 to 6t0).
conclusion: Particle B accelerates to v0 in 5t0 and decelerates to zero from 5t0 to 6t0.
Acceleration is the slope of the velocity-time graph.

premise: For particle A, during acceleration (0 to t0), velocity increases from 0 to 2v0. The slope is (2v0 - 0)/t0 = 2v0/t0.
conclusion: The acceleration of particle A during acceleration is 2v0/t0.

premise: For particle A, during deceleration (t0 to 3t0), velocity decreases from 2v0 to 0. The slope is (0 - 2v0)/(3t0 - t0) = (-2v0)/(2t0) = -v0/t0.
conclusion: The deceleration of particle A is -v0/t0.

premise: For particle B, during acceleration (0 to 5t0), velocity increases from 0 to v0. The slope is (v0 - 0)/(5t0 - 0) = v0/(5t0).
conclusion: The acceleration of particle B during acceleration is v0/(5t0).

premise: For particle B, during deceleration (5t0 to 6t0), velocity decreases from v0 to 0. The slope is (0 - v0)/(6t0 - 5t0) = -v0/t0.
conclusion: The deceleration of particle B is -v0/t0.
